title: Trump’s understaffed Cabinet is being micromanaged by the White House, leading to friction - Salon.com
text:
Wednesday, Feb 22, 2017 5:02 PM UTC Trump’s understaffed Cabinet is being micromanaged by the White House, leading to friction The White House's micromanaging may be rubbing many of its cabinet officials the wrong way Topics: Donald Trump , Rex Tillerson , robert harward , News , Politics News (Credit: AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais) 
President Donald Trump’s White House has a strange relationship with the process of hiring staffers. On the one hand, there were the staffers who, after being hired, had to be dismissed last week for failing background checks on issues like substance abuse and credit scores. Then again, the White House has been known to micromanage who its cabinet officers choose for their own staffs, according to reports. 
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson was told that he couldn’t choose a deputy who had criticized the president . Robert Harward, Trump’s first choice for national security adviser, turned him down , reportedly because he would not have been allowed to install his own staff without approval from Trump’s advisers. 
Even for the staff already installed, infighting is leading the way. 
DeVos and Attorney General Jeff Sessions feuded over Trump’s impending decision to revoke protections for transgender students’ rights according to a New York Times report . Because Trump ultimately sided with Sessions, DeVos was forced to give in since Sessions could not proceed without her cooperation. 
Trump has filled less than three dozen of the 550 top Senate-confirmed positions, according to a report by Politico . The reasons for the rejections vary aside from the common theme that their appointments would seem to bruise the president’s ego. A candidate preferred by Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos was rejected due to previously working for an organization that had supported policies which Trump opposes. Meanwhile, Secretary of Treasury Steven Mnuchin currently doesn’t have any undersecretaries or assistant secretaries, with his choices being turned down for having been insufficiently supportive of Trump in the past or being perceived as too liberal. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson couldn’t appoint Shermichael Singleton to a top position after it was discovered that Singleton had criticized Trump in the past. 
Matthew Rozsa is a breaking news writer for Salon. He holds an MA in History from Rutgers University-Newark and his work has appeared in Mic, Quartz and MSNBC.
